## Capital Structure

A firm's capital structure is the proportion of debt and equity used to finance the firm's assets.  

Whether an *optimal* capital structure exists, and the method of finding it, has long been of interest in finance. 

<div class="MIfooter"><img src="mi.png" style="height:50px;"></div> 


## Assumptions

- No taxes
- No transaction costs
- Both individials and corporations can borrow at the same rate.

<div class="MIfooter"><img src="mi.png" style="height:50px;"></div> 


## MM Proposition I (No Taxes)

`The value of the levered and unlevered firms are the same.`

## MM Proposition II (No Taxes)

The cost of equity rises linearly with leverage according to the equation:  $R_E = R_0 + \frac{D}{E}(R_0 - R_D)$, where:

- $R_E$ is the return on equity.
